QUOTE OF THE DAY"A government that robs Peter to 
      pay Paul can always depend on the support of Paul." - George 
      Bernard Shaw 



DID YOU KNOW?Worker ants may live seven years and 
      the queen may live as long as 15 years. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric… Hi everyone, This could be 
      a landmark day for immigration in the United States. Key senators from 
      both parties agreed with the White House on an immigration overhaul that 
      claims to fortify the U.S. border and quickly give legal status to the 
      millions of illegal immigrants who already live in the United States. 
      President Bush called the proposal “orderly and fair.” Sharyl 
      Attkisson will explain the plan and Sandra Hughes will look at 
      the potential political and economic ramifications. In Iraq, the 
      massive search continues for the missing U.S. soldiers from the 10th 
      Mountain Division. More than 4,000 troops were on the hunt this week, and 
      our Mark Strassmann will have a firsthand report from the area 
      that’s being searched. And to cap off our series Gotta Have It: 
      The Hard Sell to Kids, Nancy Cordes will report that Generation 
      Next is earning a new moniker: Generation Plastic. The average college 
      student graduates with more than $3,000 in credit card debt, and now 
      marketers are trying to hook kids as young as 3-years-old on spending 
      money they don’t have. We’ll wrap up tonight’s broadcast by giving 
      you a peak inside the handwritten diaries Ronald Reagan kept during his 
      eight years in the White House. What was his revelation after being shot? 
      What ailment did he warn you can catch from your kids? Join us for the 
      answers tonight. Thanks! Katie For more 
      information on these stories, please click on the following links:
Bipartisan Immigration Deal Reached Click 
      Here Census: Minority Population Tops 100M Click 
      Here And here’s a look at one of the stories we’re working 
      on for Friday’s broadcast: From picking crops in fields as a 
      migrant worker to saving lives on the operating table. You'll meet him in 
      this week's Assignment America. All that and much more, Friday, on 
      the CBS Evening News. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 



TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANJoin Dave tonight on The Late Show 
      with actor Luke Wilson AND brainy kid scientists... Don't miss a Top Ten 
      List presented by Homer Simpson. Plus, musical guest Rufus Wainwright! 
      



FRIDAY MORNING ON 
      THE EARLY SHOWHarry 
      Smith, Hannah Storm, Julie Chen and Russ 
      Mitchell anchor THE EARLY SHOW from New York. Dave 
      Price will bring us the weather. Along with the top news of 
      the day, we will also have the following stories: JUST ASK 
      A WOMAN. . . ABOUT BEING A MOTHER: No one ever said that motherhood 
      was easy. And as many know, being a mom means being hectic! In the third 
      part of our series, Just Ask A Woman, we’ll speak with women about 
      the challenges and the joys of motherhood. We will also learn more from 
      the authors of the book I Was A Really Good Mom Before I Had Kids, 
      an illuminating look at the craziness of being a mom. EARLY 
      SHOW Contributor Mary Lou Quinlan will join us with more. 
      MIKE MYERS IN SHREK THE THIRD: It has been almost four 
      years since we've seen Mike Myers on the big screen, but luckily we can 
      still hear him coming soon to a theatre near you. Thursday, Shrek The 
      Third hits the big screen and Myers once again supplies the voice to 
      everyone's favorite green Ogre. Friday morning, we’ll speak with Myers 
      about making the latest in the Shrek comedies. THAT’S THE WAY 
      IT IS: WALTER CRONKITE AT 90: It is the rare "celebrity" who is as 
      reverentially talked about by Mike Wallace and Bill Clinton as by 
      George Clooney and Robin Williams. Walter Cronkite, now 90 years of 
      age, fits that bill. The iconic newsman’s colleagues and friends will 
      celebrate his professional and personal lives in a one-hour primetime 
      special to be broadcast Friday, night on CBS. CSI BEHIND THE 
      SCENES: Another shocking season finale for powerhouse CSI. 
      Thursday night’s episode will shock fans as one of the CSI team 
      hangs on to life. And who falls victim to the "Miniature Killer" who has 
      been taunting the CSI team since last year? We’ll ask the cast 
      about the suspense-filled season-ender. BILL GEIST: WAY OFF THE 
      ROAD: For twenty years, Bill Geist has delivered the big news 
      from some of America's smallest towns. And, the Correspondent best known 
      for his reporting for CBS News' Sunday Morning, has often 
      taken us on quite an adventure. From flying with a paperboy pilot, to 
      challenging a watermelon champion speed eater, these exploits and many 
      more are featured in Bill's new book, Way Off The Road: The Peculiar 
      Charms of Small-Town America. Monday morning, Bill will join us for 
      more on his adventures and his latest book. SESAME STREET COMES 
      TO OUR STREET: Some special guests from Sesame Place--the nations only 
      theme park based on Sesame Street, will join us Friday morning. Our 
      favorite friend to tickle, Elmo, and Sesame Place’s newest resident, Abby 
      Cadabby will come visit our neighborhood. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com 


 
"THAT'S THE WAY IT IS: CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90" FRIDAY, 
      MAY 18TH (8-9pmET/PT) The world is a very different place 
      than it was in the 1960s and '70s when one voice seemed to speak for all 
      Americans and, in so doing, to bind the nation together. That unique and 
      iconic voice was, of course, Walter Cronkite's. CBS News will celebrate 
      the legendary newsman's singular life and career in a CBS News primetime 
      special, "THAT'S THE WAY IT IS - CELEBRATING CRONKITE AT 90," to be 
      broadcast Friday, May 18th (8:00-9:00 PM, ET/PT) on the CBS Television 
      Network. 



SATURDAY ON 48 
      HOURSHere's a note from Producer Miguel 
      Sancho on Saturday's 48 Hours Mystery, Beyond the 
      Boardwalk: "This report is a heartbreaker. It chronicles the 
      tragic descent of four beloved but troubled women onto the harsh streets 
      of Atlantic City, and their ultimate demise at the hands of a suspected 
      serial killer. Like any good 48 Hours Mystery episode, this 
      program provides in-depth coverage of the crime and the investigation: the 
      case is a true whodunit, replete with intriguing clues and some very 
      unusual suspects. But just as importantly, the report explores the 
      dynamics of the criminal underworld where the victims, and many young 
      women like them, found themselves trapped in a vicious cycle of 
      drug-abuse, prostitution, and violence. From a producer's 
      perspective, covering this story was an intense and harrowing experience. 
      Atlantic City is an awesome place -- in the very literal sense of 
      inspiring awe. To its great credit, Atlantic City does not pretend to be 
      Disneyland - it is an unabashed adult entertainment environment. And it 
      cannot be denied that the gaming industry has created tens of thousands of 
      jobs, and streamed countless millions of tax revenues into the state. 
      Still, when you first arrive in town, the contrast between the hulking 
      casinos and the squalor that surrounds them is a shock. Frankly the place 
      can look like a collaboration of Bukowski and Bosch. Then, as you start to 
      get a sense of how the streets operate and who the players are - the 
      not-so-hidden economy of sin-seeking tourists, drug dealers, hustlers, and 
      street-walkers - there's the thrill of gaining secret, specialized 
      knowledge. Atlantic City is, truly, one of most fascinating places I have 
      ever been, and for the journalist and the junkie alike, the action of 
      street life is an addiction all its own. But after a while, as you become 
      attached to people whose lives are so sad and hopeless, reporting becomes 
      an emotional ordeal. It is hard to wade through all the human wreckage of 
      the city's dark side without absorbing some of the suffering one 
      witnesses. After three days there, you want desperately to leave. Of 
      course once you've left you can think only about going back. It 
      may be easy for people to dismiss the murders as a story of four women who 
      succumbed to their own bad judgment and worse luck. Others may see the 
      killer as a something of an allegorical figure, a human embodiment of the 
      danger and damage of drug addiction. But if there's one thing I hope the 
      viewers remember, it is that these women, for all their problems, were 
      very real human beings. They all had families and friends who loved them. 
      They all had young children. And whatever bad choices they'd made, none of 
      them deserved this." - Miguel Sancho (48 
      Hours Mystery airs Saturday at 10pmET/9CT) If you would 
      like more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please 
      click on the following address and e-mail us at: 48hours@cbsnews.com 


 
SUNDAY 
      ON 60 
      MINUTES
DEEPWATER: The country is less secure and the U.S. 
      Coast Guard is in worse shape now than when it began its $24 billion 
      "Deepwater" refurbishment plan years ago, says a congressman overseeing 
      the maritime force. Steve Kroft reports. DUMPED ON SKID 
      ROW: Hospitals put homeless patients in a van or a taxi and drop them 
      on the city’s Skid Row, sometimes dressed in only a flimsy gown, even if 
      they're not healthy enough to fend for themselves. Anderson Cooper 
      reports on the practice known as "hospital dumping." ONE LAPTOP 
      PER CHILD: MIT Prof. Nicholas Negroponte’s dream is to put a laptop 
      computer into the hands of every child as an educational aid. Lesley 
      Stahl reports on his progress in Cambodia and Brazil.
